MID3 1993-2001:

MID4174
rivalry=2365 nationa=USA nationb=RUSSIA/USSR MID4174 19970815 -19970800 revtype1a=POLICY revtype2a=TERRITORY fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=USE OF FORCE revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

On August 15, 1997 the United States Coast Guard seized a Russian fishing boat in the Bering Sea for illegally fishing in American waters. The Russian Duma requested the ship be released in a statement on September 13. There is no indication that the boat was ever released, and some indication that the boat and its gear were confiscated by the United States. 19970815 -19970800 First day of dispute was on 8/15/1997 and last day of dispute is listed as 8/00/1997.

MID4342
rivalry=2365 nationa=RUSSIA/USSR nationb=USA MID4342 19990408 -19990419 revtype1a=POLICY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

First day of dispute was on 4/8/1999 and last day of dispute was on 4/19/1999.

MID4213
rivalry=2365 nationa=USA nationb=RUSSIA/USSR MID4213 20000202 -20000400 revtype1a=POLICY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=USE OF FORCE revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

USA patrol boats stopped and detained two Russian tankers suspected of carrying sanctioned Iraq oil from the Persian Gulf. Russian Foreign Minister demanded the immediate release of the tanker. First day of dispute was on 2/2/2000 and last day of dispute is listed as 4/00/2000.

MID4220
rivalry=2365 nationa=RUSSIA/USSR nationb=USA MID4220 20001017 -20001109 revtype1a=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0
lhostb=DISPLAY OF FORCE 

On two separate occasions (10/17/2000 and 10/19/2000) two Russian jets fly over the USS Kitty Hawk on its way to, and then from, exercises in the Korean Straits. Both times the Russian jets were chased by American F-18s. First day of dispute was on 10/17/2000 and last day of dispute was on 11/9/2000.

MID4197
rivalry=2365 nationa=RUSSIA/USSR nationb=USA MID4197 20001126 -20001200 revtype1a=OTHER revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
DISPLAY OF FORCE 

Russia deployed seven bombers capable of carrying nuclear weapons to bases in the Arctic as a "training exercise." These confrontations were routine during the Cold War but not at the time of this dispute. Canada and the United States responded by moving fighters and AWACS radar planes to northern bases to counter what NORAD described as a "potential threat." Pentagon spokesman, Kenneth Bacon stated, "We would anticipate that, in the next few days, they [the Russians] might fly one or several of these planes through the Bering Straits and close to Alaska." Russia deployed its planes sometime in late November - we assume November 26; the United States and Canada deployed their planes on November 30. It is not clear how long these deployments lasted. There is no evidence of future discussions among the participants regarding Russia's military presence in the Arctic. More specifically, it is not clear whether Russia removed its planes from the Arctic or whether Canada and United States decided to allow Russia to conduct future such training exercises in the Arctic. First day of dispute was on 11/26/2000 and last day of dispute was on 12/00/2000.

NARRATIVE-CM:
The Soviet Union and the US disputed the status of Germany after the end of the *Second World War*. On November 30, 1945, the Allied countries-the US, Soviet Union, France, and Britain-agreed to provide three air corridors to the US, France, and Britain through the Soviet zone of Germany (East Germany) to the non-Soviet zones of Berlin (West Berlin). The Soviet Union severed transportation links between West Germany and West Berlin on August 4, 1948, and the US responded by airlifting supplies to West Berlin. The US referred the matter to the *United Nations* (UN) Security Council in September 1948. The Soviet Union lifted the blockade on May 12, 1949. The *Federal Republic of Germany* (FRG) was established on September 21, 1949, and the *German Democratic Republic (GDR) was proclaimed on October 7, 1949. The Soviet Union shot down a US military aircraft over the Baltic Sea on April 8, 1950, resulting in the deaths of ten US personnel. The Soviet Union shot down a US military aircraft near Siberia on April 6, 1951, resulting in the deaths of 10 US personnel. The UN General Assembly approved a resolution on December 20, 1951 which established a commission of inquiry to investigate the possibility of German elections and reunification. The UN commission of inquiry disbanded in July 1952 after being denied access to East Germany. Soviet military aircraft shot down US military aircraft over Armenia on June 27, 1958, resulting in the detention of nine US military personnel. The Soviet Union release the nine US military personnel on July 7, 1958. Soviet military aircraft shot down US military aircraft over Armenia on September 2, 1958, resulting in the deaths of six US personnel. The Soviet Union demanded on November 27, 1958 that the US/British/French occupation of Berlin be ended, but the demand was rejected by those countries on December 31, 1958. Representatives of the four countries held negotiations concerning Berlin beginning on May 11, 1959. The countries signed an agreement on September 15, 1959, which provided for the banning of all nuclear weapons and missiles in Berlin. The Soviet Union shot down a US U-2 plane near Sverdlovsk on May 1, 1960, and protested against "aggressive acts" by the US on May 10, 1960. The Soviet Union referred the matter to the UN Security Council on May 20, 1960. East German troops and police erected a wall between East Berlin and West Berlin beginning on August 13, 1961. The US deployed an additional 1,500 troops in West Berlin on August 17-18, 1961. Soviet military aircraft shot down a US military aircraft near Erfurt, East Germany on January 28, 1964, resulting in the deaths of three US personnel. Soviet military aircraft shot down a US military aircraft near the West Germany-East Germany border on March 10, 1964, and Soviet officials released the three crew members of the military aircraft to US officials on March 21, 1964. 

The Soviet Union and US disputed the status of the Korean peninsula at the end of the *Second World War*. Soviet troops occupied Korea north of the 38th parallel, and US troops occupied Korea south of the 38th parallel. On December 27, 1945, Britain, the Soviet Union, and US agreed to establish a joint US-Soviet commission to negotiate the independence of Korea. The Soviet Union and US disagreed over the terms of Korea independence. The US referred the disagreement to the UN General Assembly in September 1947. The UN General Assembly recognized Korea's claim to independence and made plans for the establishment of a democratically-elected government on November 14, 1947. The UN General Assembly established the *United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea* (UNTCOK) on November 14, 1947 to monitor democratic elections in Korea. UNTCOK consisted of eighteen personnel from Australia, Canada, China, El Salvador, France, India, Philippines, and Syria (including 12 staff personnel from the UN Secretariat). Elections for the National Assembly were held in southern Korea on May 10, 1948. The UNTCOK supervised the elections, and issued a report on June 30, 1948. The National Assembly adopted a constitution on July 17, 1948 and elected Syngman Rhee as president on July 20, 1948. The *Republic of Korea* (South Korea) was proclaimed on August 15, 1948. The *Democratic People's Republic of Korea* (North Korea) was proclaimed on September 10, 1948. UNTCOK was dissolved on December 12, 1948. US military aircraft shot down a Soviet military aircraft near Korea on September 4, 1950, resulting in the death of three Soviet military personnel. Soviet military aircraft shot down a US military aircraft near the coast of northern Japan on October 7, 1952, resulting in the deaths of eight US military personnel. Soviet military aircraft shot down a US military aircraft over the Sea of Japan on July 29, 1953, resulting in the deaths of 16 US military personnel. Soviet military aircraft shot down a US naval aircraft near Siberian coast on September 4, 1954, resulting in the death of one US naval personnel. The US referred the matter to the UN Security Council on September 9, 1954, but the UN Security Council did not take action on the matter. Soviet military aircraft shot down a US military aircraft near the coast of northern Japan on November 7, 1954, resulting in the death of one US military personnel. Soviet military aircraft and US military aircraft clashed near North Korean coast on May 10, 1955, resulting in the downing of two Soviet aircraft. Soviet military aircraft shot down a US navy patrol plane near St. Lawrence Island in the Bering Sea on June 22, 1955. The US submitted the dispute concerning the downing of a US naval aircraft near the Siberian coast on September 4, 1954 to the *International Court of Justice* (ICJ) on August 22, 1958, but the Soviet Union rejected ICJ jurisdiction over the matter.

Prime Minister Nikita Khrushchev of the Soviet Union announced an agreement to supply arms and technical specialists to Cuba on September 2, 1962. On September 11, 1962, Prime Minister Khrushchev announced that the Soviet arms were being sent to Cuba "exclusively for defensive purposes." On October 22-23, 1962, President John Kennedy announced that the Soviet Union had deployed medium-range offensive missiles in Cuba, and ordered an air and naval blockade against all offensive military equipment being shipped to Cuba and air surveillance of Cuba beginning on October 24, 1962. On October 23, 1962, the *Organization of American States* (OAS) Council called on the Soviet Union to withdraw its offensive weapons from Cuba, and the OAS Council authorized the use of military force to ensure that "the government of Cuba cannot continue to receive from the Sino-Soviet powers military material and related supplies which may threaten the peace and stability of the continent and to prevent the missiles in Cuba with offensive capability from ever becoming an active threat to the peace and security of the continent." The Soviet Union rejected the US "quarantine" of Cuba and placed its military forces on alert on October 23, 1962. Twelve Latin American countries (Argentina, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, Venezuela) offered to provide military assistance and port facilities for military operations in the Cuban region. The UN Security Council met from October 23-24, 1962, but took no action concerning the crisis. Japan expressed support for the US on October 24, 1962. UN Secretary-General U Thant appealed for peaceful negotiations on October 24, 1963, and representaties of the Soviet Union and the US began negotiations on October 25, 1962. The Vatican appealed for peaceful negotiations on October 25, 1962. Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada expressed support for the US, and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain expressed support for the US on October 25, 1962. Soviet troops shot down a US U-2 military aircraft over Cuba on October 27, 1962, resulting in the death of one US soldier. On October 28, 1962, Prime Minister Khrushchev agreed to dismantle and remove the missiles from Cuba under UN supervision, and the US agreed to lift the blockade against Cuba. The US suspended the naval blockade against on October 30-November 1, 1962, during which UN Secretary-General U Thant traveled to Cuba for negotiations with Fidel Castro concerning on-site inspections within Cuba. Fidel Castro refused to agree to US inspection of missile bases on November 1, 1962. On November 8, 1962, the US announced that all Soviet missiles had been removed from Cuba after inspecting Soviet ships departing from Cuba. The US formally lifted the naval blockade against Cuba on November 20, 1963. On January 7, 1963, the US and Soviet Union agreed that dispute had been resolved to their satisfactions and that it was unnecessary "for this item to occupy further attention of the Security Council at this time."

SOURCES-CM: 
Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997, 332-361; Butterworth, 1976, 182-183; Clodfelter, 1992, 615-618; Donelan and Grieve, 1973, 28-32, 56-61, 168-173, 179-181, 233-237; *Facts on File*, September 3-9, 1954, September 10-16, 1954, November 5-11, 1954, July 7-13, 1955, May 5-11, 1960, October 18-24, 1962, October 25-31, 1962, November 1-7, 1962, January 30-February 5, 1964, March 5-11, 1964, March 26-April 1, 1964; *Keesing, July 17-24, 1948, November 20-27, 1948, April 29-May 6, 1950, September 9-16, 1950, July 26-August 2, 1958, May 21-28, 1960, April 11-18, 1964, June 17-24, 1972, November 18-25, 1972.

NARRATIVE-CR:

Introduction:
The rivalry between the United States and the USSR is perhaps the most intense of all the rivalries. Yet, the name given to the rivalry does not characterize it as such. The Cold War was the open yet restricted rivalry that developed after World War II between groups of nations practicing different ideologies and political systems. On one side were the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (U.S.S.R.) and its allies, often referred to as the Eastern bloc. On the other side were the United States and its allies, usually referred to as the Western bloc. The rivalry was called the Cold War because it did not actually lead to fighting, or "hot" war, on a wide scale between the principal states. The primary issues the USA and the USSR (and their respective allies) fought over were influence in and the division of Europe; perceived threats to Western Europe (from USSR) and Eastern Europe (from allies) and US. At times, the conditions of extreme distrust between the two states increased the likelihood of a third world war (Cuban Missle Crisis, Berlin Blockade, etc). The United States accused the Soviet Union of seeking to expand their version of Communism throughout the world. The Soviets charged the United States with practicing imperialism and with attempting to stop revolutionary activity in other countries. 

The Cold War continued from the end of World War II until the breakup of the Soviet Union in the early 1990s. The Korean War, the Vietnam War and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan were some of the occasions when the tension between those two states and their competing ideologies took the form of an armed conflict. However, much of the rivalry was conducted by or against surrogates and through spies and traitors who were working undercover. Thus in many of the MIDs that occur between the states the principal combatants are surrogate or allied states. In those conflicts, the major powers operated in good part by arming or funding surrogates. Hence, that part of the war at least had lessened direct impact on the populations of the major powers. 

MID197 MID2606 MID2366 all occurred in connection with the US interventions into the Russian Revolution. The rivalry between the US and the USSR began with US and Western Power intervention in the Russian Revolution. The U.S. sent troops to Archangel in September 1918, removing them in June 1919. Allied troops landed in Vladivostok in August 1918, remaining through January 1920. MID 197, `Allied intervention in Russian Civil War,' was a clash with the Soviet Union dated January 12, 1918-April 1, 1920 contains both MID 2606, `Soviet Civil-War-Intervention in Northern U.S.S.R.,' a clash dated June 28, 1918-October 12, 1919, and MID 2366, `Soviet civil war; intervention in Siberia,' an occupation of territory dated January 12, 1918-October 1, 1920. 

During World War II, the US and the USSR were allies against Germany and Japan. In the months following WWII, the rivalry between the US and USSR resumed as the Cold War commenced in 1945. 

MID252 occurred from April through October of 1945. The US sent a carrier and the battleship Missouri to Turkey. The US demonstrated resolve in support of Turkey against interference into Turkey by the USSR. 

MID26 occurred from March of 1948 until July of 1949. The Berlin blockade crisis began with continuing Soviet protests over a US policy of promoting the economic recovery of Germany and, by February of 1948, plans for a West German state. The two primary precipitants to the blockade were the publication of these plans in June of that year followed two weeks later by the introduction of a new Western currency into the three Western sectors. The USSR instituted the blockade the day after the introduction of the new Deutschmark in the Western zones. The Western powers, led by the United States, responded with a massive airlift of supplies to the encircled Berliners. (The United Kingdom and France were also significant contributors and allies of the US in this MID.)The crisis intensified over the summer and early fall as the Soviets "buzzed" US transport planes in the air corridors over East Germany, and both sides engaged in several military demonstrations of their resolve. The Western position hardened as the airlift grew in size and became more successful. Negotiations began in late August and continued sporadically through the fall and winter. An Allied attempt at action through the United Nations was blocked by a Soviet veto of a Security Council compromise solution (October 25). In January, the Allies began a "counter-blockade" of restrictions on critical goods entering the Eastern sectors of Berlin. By February 2, 1949, Stalin agreed to lift the blockade if the Allies would end the counter-blockade. After the blockade was lifted on May 12, the two sides continued negotiations for some time, but with no success at resolving the deeper issues of the ultimate status of Berlin and Germany.

MID1286 occurred from August of 1949 through November of 1951. This mid is titled `Yugoslavia vs. Cominform countries.' It is covers the rift in relations between the USSR and Yugoslavia. It pits Yugoslavia and the US v. the USSR, Bulgaria, Hungary, and Romania. The central combatants here were the USSR and Yugoslavia. This event is also described as the Yugoslav-Soviet Rift. 

In this mid Stalin feared that he was losing his grip on Eastern Europe and in 1947 ordered creation of a Soviet-dominated socialist bloc. In 1947, the Soviet, East European, Italian, and French communist parties founded the Cominform (Communist Information Bureau). Stalin saw the independent Communists in Yugoslavia as a direct threat. There were other precursors to antagonism including Stalin's wartime objections to Yugoslavian Communist political initiative, his refusal to provide aid to the Communist movement in Yugoslavia, and Red Army looting and raping in Yugoslavia in 1944 and 1945. There were also issues regarding Yugoslavia resistance to participation in Soviet economic schemes that would have had a one way beneficiary relationship towards Moscow. After a series of escalatory steps the Cominform expelled Yugoslavia and called on Yugoslav communists to overthrow Tito. At first the Yugoslav communists and Tito responded in a conciliatory fashion. Yugoslavs supported Soviet foreign policy and implemented Stalinist economic measures. However, collectivization proved disastrous as agricultural output decreased and coercive tactics used by the regime eroded support for the government. Yugoslav relations with the West in 1949 were also in a poor state as there were lingering issues with Italy over Trieste and issues with various countries over nationalized property within Yugoslavia. The Soviet-bloc governments launched an economic blockade against Yugoslavia, excluding it from the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CEMA). The Soviets propagandized harshly against "Judas" Tito in Serbo-Croatian broadcasts, attempted to subvert Yugoslav party organizations, and sought to incite unrest among the Hungarian, Albanian, and Russian minorities in Yugoslavia. Troop movements and border incidents convinced Yugoslav leaders that a Soviet-bloc invasion was imminent, requiring fundamental changes in foreign policy. In July 1949, Tito closed the Yugoslav-Greek border and ceased supplying the pro-Cominform Greek communists, and in August Yugoslav votes in the United Nations began to stray from the Soviet line. Welcoming the Yugoslav-Soviet rift, the West commenced a flow of economic aid in 1949, saved the country from hunger in 1950, and covered much of Yugoslavia's trade deficit for the next decade. The United States began shipping weapons to Yugoslavia in 1951. A military security arrangement was concluded in 1953, but the Western powers were unable to bring Yugoslavia into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). During the mid their were minor skirmishes on the border and a US cargo aircraft carrying supplies to Yugoslavia was forced to land in Hungary but subsequently allowed to proceed. 

MID50 occurred from February of 1953 through November of 1956. The primary combatants in this conflict were the PRC and Taiwan. Here the USSR assisted the PRC in a four-day operation designed to show support for the PRC in hostilities toward Taiwan. During the First Taiwan Straits Crisis the Peoples Liberation Army launched heavy artillery attacks on the offshore island of Quemoy after the US lifted its blockade of Taiwan, making possible Nationalist attacks on mainland China. The Truman Administration had resisted calls by hard-liners to "unleash Chiang Kai-shek." However, shortly after his inauguration, on 02 February 1953 President Eisenhower lifted the US Navy blockade of Taiwan that had prevented Chiang's force from attacking mainland China. During August 1954, Chiang moved 58,000 troops to Quemoy & 15,000 to Matsu. Zhou En-lai declared on 11 August 1954 that Taiwan must be liberated. On 17 August 1954, the US warned China against action against Taiwan, but on 03 September 1954, the Communists began an artillery bombardment of Quemoy, and in November, PLA planes bombed the Tachen Islands. On 12 September 1954, the US Joint Chiefs of Staff (JCS) recommended the possibility of using nuclear weapons against China. Moreover, on 23 November 1954 China sentenced 13 US airmen shot down over China in the Korean War to long jail terms, prompting further consideration of nuclear strikes against China. Despite domestic political pressure, President Eisenhower refused to bomb mainland China or use of American troops to resolve the crisis. At the urging of Senator Knowland, the United States signed the Mutual Defense Treaty with the Nationalist government on Taiwan on 02 December 1954. On 18 January 1955 mainland Chinese forces seized Yijiangshan [Ichiang] Island, 210 miles north of Formosa and, completely wiping out the ROC forces stationed there. The two sides continued fighting on Kinmen, Matsu, and along the mainland Chinese coast. The fighting even extended to mainland Chinese coastal ports. The US-Nationalist Chinese Mutual Security Pact, which did not apply to islands along the Chinese mainland, was ratified by the Senate on 09 February 1955. The Formosa Resolution passed both houses of Congress on 29 January 1955. The Resolution pledged the US to the defense of Taiwan, authorizing the president to employ American forces to defend Formosa and the Pescadores Island against armed attack, including such other territories as appropriate to defend them. On 23 April 1995, China stated at the Afro-Asian Conference that it was ready to negotiate on Taiwan, and on 01 May 1955, shelling of Quemoy-Matsu ceased, ending the crisis. On 01 August 1955 China released the 11 captured US airmen previously sentenced to jail terms. In the first Taiwan Strait crisis of 1954-55 the USSR had been quite ambiguous in its support for China's campaign to "liberate" Taiwan, whereas the United States had indicated that it was willing to use tactical nuclear weapons in defense of the island. During the crisis, it became evident that the USSR was not going to be drawn into a war with the United States that was not of its own choosing, and the PRC called off its military operations against Quemoy. The PRC could claim a limited victory because Chinese Nationalist troops had withdrawn from Tachen Island during the previous month. Even as the crisis ended, however, the Nationalists began to reinforce Quemoy and Matsu, and the PRC began to build up its military capabilities across the strait.

MID208 occurred in March of 1953. It is a multilateral dispute with the US and the UK versus the USSR and Czechoslovakia. Czechoslovakia sentenced William Oatis, a press correspondent from the US, to a ten-year prison sentence for espionage on July 4, 1951. The US responded by imposing economic sanctions against Czechoslovakia. Czechoslovak military aircraft shot down a US military aircraft over the US occupation zone in Germany on March 10, 1953. Czechoslovakia released William Oatis from prison on May 15, 1953, and the US lifted economic sanctions against Czechoslovakia on May 16, 1953. 

MID200. The next significant point of conflict between Israel and Egypt was the Sinai War MID200. `In early 1955, Egypt began sponsoring raids launched by fedayeen (Arab commandos or guerrillas) from the Sinai Peninsula, the Gaza Strip, and Jordan, into Israel. As the number and seriousness of these raids increased, Israel began launching reprisal raids against Arab villages in Gaza and the West Bank of the Jordan. These retaliatory measures, which cost the lives of Arab civilians and did little to discourage the fedayeen, became increasingly controversial both within Israel and abroad. Shortly thereafter Israeli reprisal raids were directed against military targets, frontier strongholds, police fortresses, and army camps.' `In addition to these incidents, that at times became confrontations between regular Israeli and Arab military forces, other developments contributed to the generally escalating tensions between Egypt and Israel and convinced Israeli military officials that Egypt was preparing for a new war. Under an arms agreement of 1955, Czechoslovakia supplied Egypt with a vast amount of arms, including fighter aircraft, tanks and other armored vehicles, destroyers, and submarines. The number of Egyptian troops deployed in Sinai along the Israeli border also increased dramatically in 1956. In July Egypt nationalized the Suez Canal; shortly thereafter Egypt closed the Strait of Tiran, at the southern tip of Sinai, and blockaded Israeli shipping. Fearing these actions to be signs of an imminent Egyptian invasion, Israel rapidly mobilized its reserves. On October 29, under Major General Moshe Dayan, the IDF launched a preemptive attack into Sinai. Israeli advances on the ground were rapid, and, supported by air cover, by November 2 they had routed the Egyptian forces and effectively controlled the entire peninsula. With Israeli troops on the east bank of the Suez Canal, British and French troops landed at Port Said and demanded withdrawal of both sides from the Canal. The UN met in an emergency session and demanded that the British and French leave Suez, which they did in December 1956 in response to both United States and UN pressure, and that Israel withdraw to the Armistice line of 1949, which it did somewhat reluctantly in March 1957 after the United Nations Emergency Force (UNEF) had been stationed in the Gaza Strip and at Sharm ash Shaykh on the Strait of Tiran. Israel's victory in the 1956 Sinai War thus afforded it a modicum of increased security by virtue of the UN presence. Far more important, however, was that it enhanced Israel's standing as a military power and as a viable nation. Although many Israelis felt that the military victory was nullified by the UN demand to withdraw from Sinai, Israel had achieved significant psychological gains at a cost of fewer than 170 lives.' 

MID607 occurred from April through November of 1957. This is a multilateral mid whose principal combatants were Turkey and Syria. Also included in the mid were Jordan and Iraq allied with Turkey and the United States. The USSR and Egypt were allied with Syria. This was a border dispute between the two countries that spiraled to the point of open hostilities. In April of 1957, the Turks began to position troops near the Syrian border. This provoked a corresponding troop build up from the Syrians. Both sides alleged that they were conducting `normal' maneuvers. The Turks and the Syrians suffered dozens of casualties in the tension as minor flare ups occurred late in the mid. Both the Egyptians and the Americans were heavily involved in this mid. The Americans shipped arms in support of the Turks while the Egyptians supplied up to 15,000 troops to support the Syrians. 

MID125 occurred in 1958. It is a multilateral mid involving the US and the UK v. the USSR, Iraq, and Egypt. Lebanon was in a civil war at the time. The state of turmoil increased when, in the early hours of July 14, 1958, a revolution overthrew the monarchy in Iraq and the entire royal family was killed. The revolution was received warmly in Lebanon in areas where the population was against the government of Shamun. Radio stations announced that the Shamun regime would be next. Shamun, realizing the gravity of his situation, summoned the ambassadors of the United States, Britain, and France on the morning of July 14. He requested immediate assistance, insisting that the independence of Lebanon was in jeopardy. The US and the UK landed troops in Lebanon in support of the Shamun regime. 

MID2215 occurred from June 27-July 7 of 1958. It is titled `Soviet downing of a C-118 transport plane.' The plane was shot down over Soviet Armenia on June 27. The crew was released on July 7. This incident did not result in a change in the makeup of American forces. 

MID173 occurred from July through December of 1958. This dispute was between the PRC and Taiwan. The USSR assisted the PRC while the US assisted Taiwan. On August 23, China again shelled the islands of Quemoy and Matsu. President Eisenhower responds by sending U.S. forces, including a large naval contingent, to the Taiwan Strait. The U.S. even explores the option of using nuclear weapons against China. The crisis is diffused when China suspends its bombing campaign after high-level talks with the U.S.

MID608 November 7, 1958-June 23, 1959. This mid is closely related to MID2216 which occurred on November 7th 1958. These events are a show of troops also involving France, Britain, against the Soviet Union. The mid is titled `1958-1959 Berlin Deadline Crisis.' In November 1958, Soviet Premier Khrushchev issued an ultimatum giving the Western powers six months to agree to withdraw from Berlin and make it a free, demilitarized city. At the end of that period, Khrushchev declared, the Soviet Union would turn over to East Germany complete control of all lines of communication with West Berlin; the western powers then would have access to West Berlin only by permission of the East German government. The United States, Great Britain, and France replied to this ultimatum by firmly asserting their determination to remain in West Berlin and to maintain their legal right of free access to that city. In 1959 the Soviet Union withdrew its deadline and instead met with the Western powers in a Big Four foreign ministers' conference. Although the three-month-long sessions failed to reach any important agreements, they did open the door to further negotiations and led to Premier Khrushchev's visit to the United States in September of 1959. At the end of this visit, Khrushchev and President Eisenhower stated jointly that the most important issue in the world was general disarmament and that the problem of Berlin and "all outstanding international questions should be settled, not by the application of force, but by peaceful means through negotiations." 

MID246 is the Bay of Pigs Invasion. The 1959 takeover of Cuba by Fidel Castro and his revolutionary followers prompted the exodus of many Cubans, especially to the United States. When Castro's communist-oriented regime confiscated private property and established close ties to the Soviet Union, the United States imposed an embargo on all exports to Cuba (except food and medicine) and broke diplomatic relations (1960-61). Anti-Castro Cuban exiles demanded that the United States back an invasion of their homeland to topple the government; as early as 1960, the American Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) began to train an exile army in Guatemala. On April 17, 1961, about 1,400 exiles invaded southern Cuba at the Bahia de los Cochinos (Bay of Pigs), but were totally defeated by the Cuban army by April 20; most of the invaders were killed or taken prisoner. Critics of this failure blamed the last-minute withdrawal of naval air support by US president John F. Kennedy, but closer investigation disclosed that the CIA scheme, meant to be secret but long a matter of public knowledge, had been based on faulty intelligence information, was poorly planned, and ultimately was poorly executed. The failed invasion aggravated already hostile US-Cuban relations and eventually required the expediture of $53 million in food and medicine (raised by private donors to meet Casto's ransom) to secure the release of the 1,113 surviving captive invaders.

MID253 occurred from May through July of 1960. It is called U-2 and RB-47 incidents. Soviet forces shot down an American U-2 reconnaissance plane in Soviet airspace, capturing its pilot, Francis Gary powers (May 1). Powers was imprisoned as a spy and later exchanged for Soviet spy Rudolph Abel (February 1962).

MID1363 occurred from December 29, 1960 until April 20, 1961. In 1961, there was an internationalized civil war within Laos. North Vietnam, the USSR, and the Peoples Republic of China supported the Communist forces in northern Laos. The Royal Laotian Government (RLG) was supported by the USA and Thailand. There was considerable direct support from both the USA and the USSR. The USSR was airlifting supplies to the Pathet Lao while the USA was flying reconnaissance missions in support of the RLG. Neither the USA nor the USSR wanted the conflict to break out into a direct conflict between them. There was a push to resolve the conflict with a conference in Geneva. While preliminary discussion about having the conference in Geneva were ongoing, the Kennedy administration discussed intervention by SEATO. China warned Washington and Laos that should SEATO intervene it would intervene with direct military force. This threat constitutes MID1363.

MID27 is the Berlin Wall Crisis. This is a multilateral dispute involving many countries including the US in opposition to Czechoslovakia. The Berlin dispute had simmered ever since Khrushchev threatened (1958) to sign a separate peace treaty with East Germany. This action would seriously threaten the status of West Berlin, as well as Western access to the city.The Soviets, for their part, were particularly concerned with the growing military strength of West Germany, and, in particular, the installation of tactical nuclear weapons in West Germany. The East German government was increasingly concerned about the defection of East German citizens moving from East to West Berlin. On June 4, 1961, Khrushchev reissued his 1958 threat in ultimatum form, with a deadline of December 31, 1961. Kennedy responded (June 28, July 25) with a public statement of the US determination to defend the status of Berlin, including Western access rights, but with no mention of freedom of movement between East and West Berlin. This may have encouraged the Soviet and East German governments to begin construction of the Berlin Wall on August 13, 1961. That action produced an immediate heightening of tensions, including shows-of-strength and diplomatic sanctions by both sides. By the end of August Kennedy proposed negotiations which were arranged for September 21 in New York. Conciliatory letters between Kennedy and Khrushchev were exchanged in late September. When Kennedy assured Khrushchev that the US would not pursue the reunification of Germany, Khrushchev decided (October 17) to rescind the December 31 deadline for a settlement. Tentative agreement on a formula for a negotiated settlement regarding access right and recognition of the boundaries of the two Germanies was reached on November 9th, although it was to take more than a decade before a formal agreement was reached.

MID2217 is a bilateral mid that occurred July 25-September 7. The mid is called `Operation Mongoose.' This was a covert U.S. effort to overthrow Fidel Castro after the failure of the Bay of Pigs invasion. It continued throughout the Kennedy administration but was not an overt use of force. 

MID2219 is a multilateral mid with the US and West Germany v. the USSR and East Germany that occurred from December of 1961 until October of 1962. This mid covers a period of several minor incidents that all served to increase hostilities. In December, the East Germans and the Soviets protested to the United States regarding hostile troop movements along the autobahn link connecting Berlin with West Germany. This was followed by the East German shooting of an American military vehicle that was part of the US mission in Potsdam. 

MID3361 occurs from December of 1961 until March of 1962. Here the United States built up its military force in South Vietnam in support of that nation. The PRC and the USSR threatened that the build up was precipitating war. The PRC and the USSR were supporting Hanoi at the time. The PRC noted that US military escalation in S. Vietnam threatened the security of North Vietnam, its ally in the region. 

MID1353 takes place during the second Laotian Civil War that occurs from 1963 until 1973. China is involved in direct support of the Pathet Lao from May of 1962 until July of 1964. China provided direct aid to the communist forces in Laos and conducted direct military operations in Northern Laos. Much of the activity China was involved in centered on completing a road network in Northern Laos that would connect North Vietnam, Laos and Thailand. The road network would provide access of supplies and troops for the communist groups in all three countries. Chinese forces were also involved in direct military confrontation with the Royal Laotian Government. Both the United States and the Soviet Union were involved in this dispute though on a limited scale in support of there Cold War allies. 

MID2899 occurred on March 15, 1963. It is a bilateral one day mid. On this date, Soviet aircraft violated U.S. airspace over Alaska eliciting an American diplomatic protest but no military action.

MID2218 is a mid that relates to the security of Berlin. It occurred on April 2, 1963. 

MID 2220 is a border violation involving the Soviet Union, that occurred from January 28-March 27 of 1964. On January 28, an American training plane was shot down over East Germany. On March 10, an American reconnaissance aircraft was shot down under similar circumstances. The crew was returned on March 27. 

MID 2909 also involved the Soviet Union, took place January 28-March 10. There is no record of this dispute in the news sources or text sources cited below. 

MID611 is the Vietnam War. Here the United States intervened to help South Vietnam resist subjugation by their northern neighbor, North Vietnam. North Vietnam was also receiving aid from China and the USSR during the conflict. The loss of Southeast Asia was defined as threatening the security of the United States and the collectivity of Western nations. `The sovereignties of Vietnam and other Southeast Asian countries were valued not on their own merit but rather as a test of U.S. global position and credibility perception that would have a profound impact on the nature on the decision to intervene. Vietnam became important for what its loss to the communists would portend.' US hostilities towards N. Vietnam ended in January of 1973. The last American troops left S. Vietnam in March of 1973. 

MID2901 Dispute involving the United States and the Soviet Union. There is no mention of this incident in the news sources or text sources listed below. 

MID2910 A show of planes initiated by the United States involving the Soviet Union, June 12. There is no mention of this incident in the news sources or text sources listed below. 

MID2921 occurred on July 15, 1966. This is the US identification of a Soviet submarine base in Cuba. 

MID2934 occurred from March 2-22, 1967. A Soviet fishing vessel was fined for fishing in U.S. waters near Alaska 

MID2931 occurred on April 28, 1967. The Soviets claimed two U.S. planes buzzed their aircraft off the Greek coast on this date.

MID2930 occurred in May of 1967. Here the United States was conducting naval training operations in the Sea of Japan with the Japanese and the South Koreans. These operations were conducted within a few hundred miles of Soviet territory. Soviet ships and warplanes shadowed these exercises and on two occasions got so close to the American ships that the ships collided. The Americans claimed that the Soviets intentionally collided with the US ships but the Soviets claimed it was an accident. 

MID345 is the US and USSR interactions related to the Arab Israeli War in 1967. This event is a show of ships involving the Soviet Union and Israel, June 10-19. President Johnson ordered the 6th Fleet to move within 50 miles of the Syrian coast in order to signal the Soviets not to intervene in the war. 

MID2928 is a bilateral mid that occurred from June 30-July 2 1968. A U.S. airliner chartered by Military Airlift Command bound for Cambodia was intercepted by Soviet aircraft off the Kurile islands. No shots were fired. 

MID2941 occurred in April of 1969. North Korean military aircraft shot down a US military aircraft (US navy EC-121 reconnaissance plane) over the Sea of Japan on April 15, 1969, resulting in the deaths of 31 US military personnel. The US deployed 29 naval ships in the Sea of Japan beginning on April 21, 1969. The Soviet Union protested the deployment of US naval ships in the Sea of Japan on April 22, 1969, and the US withdrew its naval ships from the Sea of Japan on April 26, 1969. 

MID3241 is associated with events surrounding the Jordanian Civil War of 1970. This event involved Jordan, Syria, Libya, Iraq, the US, the USSR and the UK. The U.S. ordered three aircraft carriers to the Middle East and alerted ground forces in order to warn the Syrians against intervention in ongoing Jordanian civil strife. MID 3241 involves many of the same Arab countries and also the USSR and is dated September 18-26. 

MID 2221 is a border violation, October 10-November 10 of 1970. A plane flying near Soviet Armenia and Turkey was forced down in Armenia by Soviet intercept planes after it strayed into Soviet air space. The plane carried two US generals. The generals and two other were released unharmed on November 10, 1970. 

MID2949 occurred in 1972. This was a seizure involving the United States and the Soviet Union. The US Coast Guard seized a Soviet fishing vessel and arrested its captain for fishing illegally and attempting to flee. 

MID353 occurred in October of 1973. This was a multilateral mid with the US allied with Israel v Egypt, Syria, and the USSR. The principal combatants here were the US and the USSR both displaying force. All parties were involved in the dispute for the duration of the mid. This mid is concurrent with the Yom Kippur War. Essentially, this mid codes the moves of support that the US and the USSR make in support of their allies in the Yom Kippur War. Both the US and the USSR made unusually large shipments of armaments to their allies during the war. 

MID2222 is called the `Seizure of two fishing boats.' It is a seizure involving the Soviet Union, April 9-10 1977. Two Soviet fishing boats were seized off the New England coast for violating the 200-mile territorial waters limit.

MID2223 occurred from November 19, 1978-January 2, 1979 and is associated with the political crisis in Iran. In this crisis, the US sent war ships to the region as a show of force. 

MID2224 is titled a `Capture of U.S. torpedo boat' that occurred on August of 9 and 10 1979. A show of ships involving the Soviet Union, August 9-
10. There is no mention of this event in contemporary news sources or in the text sources cited below. 

MID2225 Soviet troops in Cuba, October. Incident 17 (level 3) in Zelikow (1987). MID 2225 (`Soviet Combat Unit in Cuba') is a show of troops involving Cuba and the Soviet Union, August 31-November 20

MID2226 `Baltic Sea maneuvers' coded as a show of ships involving the Soviet Union and several NATO countries, May 13-19. This incident is not mentioned in FF 1980 or KCA 1980.

MID2227 is called `U.S. threat after Tito's death' is coded as a threat of force involving the Soviet Union on May 4. President Carter affirmed U.S. support for Yugoslavian independence on May 4, 1980, during a visit to the country. Carter had stated at a news conference on February 13 that the United States would assist Yugoslavia in resisting Soviet intimidation.

MID2228 is called `U.S. seizure of Soviet cargo' is coded as a seizure initiated by the United States involving the Soviet Union, May 12-14. U.S. Customs inspectors held Soviet air cargo at Dulles airport until it was discovered that only minor paperwork violations could be found. The Soviets protested, but took no other action.

MID 2229 (`Militarization of Kurile Islands') is a show of planes involving the United States and Japan, September 30, 1982-January 24, 1983. On September 30, 1982, the United States announced plans to deploy up to 50 F-16s to Honshu by 1985. Japan announced its intentions to increase military cooperation with the United States on January 18, 1983, prompting Soviet criticism. 

MID2982 occurred on December 16, 1982. This is a bilateral dispute. On this date, the Soviets briefly detained two American journalists who had contacted Jewish dissidents, but the American embassy had no comment when asked about the incident. 

MID2231 occurred from November 24, 1983-May 20, 1984. It is called the Deployment of Soviet SS-22 missiles and U.S. Pershing missiles.' In this mid the USSR, the USA, W. Germany and Czechoslovakia displayed threatening behavior toward one another in a show of their respective warplanes. 

MID2230 is a bilateral dispute with the USSR that occurred September 12-19. The Soviets seized a U.S. commercial vessel that accidentally ventured into Soviet waters near Alaska. The ship was released after American protests

MID2232 occurred in 1985. Here the Soviet military shot a US military officer. The officer was in East Germany at the time observing Soviet tank maneuvers. The Soviets and the Allied powers agreed to what amounted to sanctioned espionage in 1947. A limited number of intelligence troops from the United States were permitted to observe Soviet activities in East Germany and vice versa. Accounts over the incident are in dispute over the actual events of the shooting. The Soviets claimed that the major was in a restricted area when he was shot and ignored warning shots. The Americans claimed that the major was shot without warning and that he was not in a restricted area. Incidents involving these sanctioned espionage agents were frequent. American, French and British military officials occupied various cities in East Germany and the Soviets occupied several cities in West Germany. Americans reported being rammed in their cars, being harassed in person, and being variously harassed by the Soviet and East German troops. 

MID3637 is a bilateral dispute that occurred on January 7 1986. In this MID the USSR took the action of displaying force. There is no mention of this incident in any of the news sources or text sources cited below. 

MID2233 occurred on 3/18/1986. Here a US guided missile cruiser and destroyer traveled near the Crimean coast to test right of innocent passage, prompting Soviet protests.

Termination Factors:

Between November 1982 and March 1985, the Soviet Union had four general secretaries (Brezhnev, Andropov, Chernenko, and Gorbachev) while the United States had a single chief executive. The changes of leadership in the Soviet Union had a noticeable effect on Soviet-American relations. Until Gorbachev assumed power and partially consolidated his rule by 1986, the frequent changes in Soviet leadership resulted in the continuation of policies formulated during the late Brezhnev period. Soviet foreign policy toward the United States during this period increasingly took the form of vituperative propaganda attacks on Reagan, who, it was alleged, was personally responsible for derailing Soviet-American detente and increasing the danger of nuclear war. The low point in Soviet-American relations occurred in March 1983, when Reagan described the Soviet Union as an "evil empire . . . the focus of evil in the modern world," and Soviet spokesmen responded by attacking Reagan's "bellicose, lunatic anticommunism." The Soviet shoot-down of a civilian South Korean airliner in September 1983 near the Soviet island of Sakhalin shocked world public opinion and militated against any improvement in Soviet-American relations at that time. In 1983, the United States was increasingly concerned about Soviet activities in Grenada, finally directing the military operation in October 1983 that was denounced by the Soviet Union. In November 1983, the Soviet negotiators walked out of the arms control talks. 

On the death of Konstantin Chernenko, Mikhail Gorbachev, at age 54, was elected General Secretary of the Communist Party on March 11, 1985. As the de facto ruler of the Soviet Union, he tried to reform the stagnating Communist Party rule by introducing glasnost ("openness") and perestroika ("restructuring") which were launched at the 27th Congress of CPSU in February 1986. 

In August 1985, Gorbachev declared a unilateral moratorium on nuclear testing. The United States, in the midst of a nuclear warhead modernization program, refused to go along with the moratorium. Some Western analysts viewed Gorbachev's unilateral moratorium as a Soviet attempt to delay weapons modernization in the United States and, in the event that the United States refused to abide by the moratorium even unofficially, an attempt to depict the United States and the Reagan administration as militaristic. The Soviet Union ended the moratorium with an underground nuclear test in February 1987. 

A general improvement in Soviet-American relations began soon after Gorbachev was selected general secretary in March 1985. Annual summit meetings between Reagan and Gorbachev were held at Geneva (November 1985); Reykjavik (October 1986); Washington (December 1987); and Moscow (May 1988). 

During the mid-to late 1980s, the Soviet Union also stepped up media contacts. Soviet spokesmen appeared regularly on United States television, United States journalists were allowed unprecedented access to report on everyday life in the Soviet Union, and video conferences (termed "tele-bridges") were held between various United States groups and selected Soviet citizens. 

In 1988, Gorbachev announced that the Soviet Union would abandon the Brezhnev Doctrine, and allow the Eastern European countries to turn to democracy, if they wished. He jokingly called his new doctrine the Sinatra Doctrine. By 1989 there was widespread unrest in Eastern Europe. Gorbachev did not intervene as these countries cut their ties with the Soviet Union. The Berlin Wall, the major symbol of communist oppression, was torn down in November. In less than a year, East and West Germany became one nation again. A few months after that, the Warsaw Pact was dissolved. With the exception of Romania, the collapses of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe were all peaceful. This effectively ended the Cold War, and for this, Gorbachev was awarded the Nobel peace prize on October 15, 1990. However, despite the end of the Cold War, there have been several mids between the US and Russia since 1989-1991. 

MID4174 On August 15, 1997 the United States Coast Guard seized a Russian fishing boat in the Bering Sea for illegally fishing in American waters. The Russian Duma requested the ship be released in a statement on September 13. There is no indication that the boat was ever released, and some indication that the boat and its gear were confiscated by the United States. 

MID4213 USA patrol boats stopped and detained two Russian tankers suspected of carrying sanctioned Iraq oil from the Persian Gulf. Russian Foreign Minister demanded the immediate release of the tanker.

MID4220 On two separate occasions (10/17/2000 and 10/19/2000) two Russian jets fly over the USS Kitty Hawk on its way to, and then from, exercises in the Korean Straits. Both times the Russian jets were chased by American F-18s. 

MID4197 Russia deployed seven bombers capable of carrying nuclear weapons to bases in the Arctic as a "training exercise." These confrontations were routine during the Cold War but not at the time of this dispute. Canada and the United States responded by moving fighters and AWACS radar planes to northern bases to counter what NORAD described as a "potential threat." Pentagon spokesman, Kenneth Bacon stated, "We would anticipate that, in the next few days, they [the Russians] might fly one or several of these planes through the Bering Straits and MID Number Storyclose to Alaska." Russia deployed its planes sometime in late November-we assume November 26; the United States and Canada deployed their planes on November 30. It is not clear how long these deployments lasted. There is no evidence of future discussions among the participants regarding Russia's military presence in the Arctic. More specifically, it is not clear whether Russia removed its planes from the Arctic or whether Canada and United States decided to allow Russia to conduct future such training exercises in the Arctic. 

MID4241 is a Russian display of force against the US in September of 2001. The US took no military action. I was not able to locate reference to this incident in the news or text sources cited below. 

SOURCES-CR:
Beede 1994, 380-2; Berman and Routh, 2003; Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997, 332-361; Butterworth, 1976, 182-183; Clodfelter, 1992, 615-618; Donelan and Grieve, 1973, 28-32, 56-61, 168-173, 179-181, 233-237; Dunbabin 1994, 64, 211-5; Emerson 1974, 105-9; Facts on File 1946, 109, 1958, 217, 1963, 94-5, 1964, 33, 73, 97, 1967, 110, 208, 1970, 708, 670-1, 1972, 29, 1977, 269, 1980, 110, 1982, 754, 1983, 26, 1984, 727, 1986,183, September 3-9, 1954, September 10-16, 1954, November 5-11, 1954, July 7-13, 1955, May 5-11, 1960, October 18-24, 1962, October 25-31, 1962, November 1-7, 1962, January 30-February 5, 1964, March 5-11, 1964, March 26-April 1, 1964; Fursenko and Naftali 1997, 63-4; Globalsecurity.org; Grimmett 1999, 13; Kaplan and Blechman 1978; Keesings Contemporary Archive 1959, 16803; 1963/4 19890; 3/87, 35008; *Keesing, July 17-24, 1948, November 20-27, 1948, April 29-May 6, 1950, September 9-16, 1950, July 26-August 2, 1958, May 21-28, 1960, April 11-18, 1964, June 17-24, 1972, November 18-25, 1972; NYT 11/10/1970; 11/29/67; 12/17/82; 12/30/82; 7/1/68; Onwar.com; Prados 1996, 194-217

SB-CR:
United States / USSR Years: 1946-Present. Issues at stake: Influence in and the division of Europe; perceived threats to Western Europe (from USSR) and Eastern Europe (from US and allies). End coding: Continuing as of 1988. Number of reciprocated 30 day militarized disputes: 20. Last militarized dispute: As recent as 1986. Wars: None. Summary: At the end of WWII, growing US-Soviet hostility resulted in the maintenance by both superpowers of large numbers of troops facing each other across the German border. While most observers agree that Europe was the center of the confrontation, this hostility reflected itself in conflicts in several areas, including the Middle East, Southeast Asia, the Caribbean, and Africa, as any perceived "expansion" by either side was met with a response. Disputes were frequent, although none escalated to war (the dyad is quite unusual in the high number of disputes coupled with low number of wars). As of the late 1980s, tensions were still high and disputes continued. Notes: Although the rivalry is coded as continuing as of 1988, 1989 could be interpreted as the end of the rivalry when the USSR did not intervene in the revolutions in Eastern European, allowing changes in governments and the unification of Germany. This was followed by the beginning of Soviet troop withdrawal from Eastern Europe. Gorbachev's reform programs began in 1988 when the Communist party gave him broad powers to make reform, followed by his election within the Soviet Congress in a competitive race (perhaps marking the beginning of democratization). Sources: Goldstein and Freeman (1990), Huth, Bennett, and Gelpi (1992).

NARRATIVE-PS:

19891109-19920201 Transition

On November 9, 1989 the Berlin Wall came down, marking, for many, the beginning of the end of the cold war era. In 1990-91 the Soviet Union/Russia supported sanction and operations during the Persian Gulf crisis. On July 1, 1991 Warsaw Pact, the alliance system established in 1951 to balance a perceived threat from the NATO alliance, ceased to exist as an organization. The Soviet Union officially dissolved on December 25, 1991 when President Gorbachev stepped down, declaring that the office of the president of the Soviet Union no longer existed.

19920202-20159999 .25

On February 1, 1992, during negotiations between US President G.H.W. Bush and Russian President B. Yeltsin, the two leaders announced a new level of bilateral relations and officially declared an end to the Cold War. The declaration begins a phase in US-Russian relations that enjoy a higher degree of peaceful and cooperative interaction. During the 1990s the two countries sign numerous agreements calling for greater cooperation in areas of economic policy, education, non-proliferation, and strategic military policy. In April of 1993 the two countries participate in the first post-Cold War joint military exercises. This is only the first of many joint military exercises between the new strategic partners carried out during the 1990s. On January 14, 1994 U.S. President B. Clinton and Russian President B. Yeltsin sign the Moscow Declaration; this declaration, put into effect on May 30, 1994, `discontinues the aiming of strategic nuclear weapons at US and Russian territories.' In May of 1997 Russia was invited to participate in a NATO conference in Paris. In the aftermath of the September 11th terrorist attacks, the NATO-Russian Council was established (NRC) to promote greater cooperation and consultation regarding military action and general security, especially in European security. The U.S. also views Russia as a strategic partner in maintaining peace and stability in Russia's border regions.

Following the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Russia began consulting with the G-7 group. In 1994 the group was unofficially referred to as the G-7 plus 1 to denote Russia's higher level of participation. By the 1997 meeting, Russia's greater involvement was marked by creation of the G-8. On January 1, 2006 Russia's president Putin assumed the rotating presidency of the group, with the 2006 meeting of the G-8 hosted by Russia in St. Petersburg.

Relations between the two countries have improved considerably. The U.S. State Department declared in 2002 that the two countries are no longer rivals. Indeed, the Russian President Vladimir Putin suggested in February 2005 that the two countries' relations, despite disagreement on several important issues, have never been better. However, there are still lingering issues between the two countries. US abandonment of the 1972 ABM treaty caused considerable tension between the two countries in 2002 and prompted Russia to announce that is would no longer feel bound by the START-2 treaty. There are many unresolved issues in general regarding the disposition of nuclear weapons and proliferation. The two countries have also had considerable disagreement over the disposition of Iranian and North Korean nuclear programs, as well as the U.S. invasion of Iraq.

The United States and Russia experienced four disputes during the post-Cold War era. These disputes, however, are not related to the Cold War rivalry. In addition, each dispute is an isolated incident unconnected to the other disputes during this period. In 1997 (mid 4174), a Russia fishing boat violated US territorial waters prompting the United States to seize and hold the vessel. The second mid (4213) involved the perceived violation of sanctions against Iraq by a Russian oil tanker. In 2000, on two occasions Russian fighter jets flew over a US naval vessel during exercise (mid 4220). Also in 2000, Russia deployed bombers capable of carrying nuclear weapons to the Artic for the first time in ten years. The action prompted the United States and Canada to deploy reconnaissance and fighter aircraft to bases in Alaska. Only the last event (mid 4220) seems connected to Cold War issues; the rest all are relatively low level incidents. Although the immediate threat of war and the overall hostility level have diminished, the persistence of periodic disputes suggests that there is much yet to resolve between these two countries.

The first event of RIV77 is MID252 in 1945. The last recorded military event of RIV77 is MID2233 in March of 1986. The last recorded military event between the two states is MID4241 in September of 2001. The two countries clearly experience a transition between 1989 and 1992; RIV77 comes to an end in 1989. There are still post-cold war disputes, however, indicating that relations are still contentious. Therefore, post-1992 the dyad is coded as a .75.

PS-SOURCES: 

Mosnew.com February 1, 2005; US Embassy-Moscow, 2006; United States Department of State December 5, 2002 October 2004

MARITIME-MIDS: MID2949 MID2222 MID4174 

MARITIME-LAST-CHECKED: 20141229 

MID2934 MID2930 MID2941 MID2224 MID2230 MID4213 not considered maritime MIDs 

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID2934
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19670302 19670322
 HOSTILITYA: 4 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 1 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID2934 occurred from March 2-22, 1967. A Soviet fishing vessel was fined for fishing in U.S. waters near Alaska 

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID2930
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19670510 19670517
 HOSTILITYA: 1 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 4 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID2930 occurred in May of 1967. Here the United States was conducting naval training operations in the Sea of Japan with the Japanese and the South Koreans. These operations were conducted within a few hundred miles of Soviet territory. Soviet ships and warplanes shadowed these exercises and on two occasions got so close to the American ships that the ships collided. The Americans claimed that the Soviets intentionally collided with the US ships but the Soviets claimed it was an accident. 

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID2941
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19690418 19690427
 HOSTILITYA: 3 FATALITYA: 2
 HOSTILITYB: 1 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID2941 occurred in April of 1969. North Korean military aircraft shot down a US military aircraft (US navy EC-121 reconnaissance plane) over the Sea of Japan on April 15, 1969, resulting in the deaths of 31 US military personnel. The US deployed 29 naval ships in the Sea of Japan beginning on April 21, 1969. The Soviet Union protested the deployment of US naval ships in the Sea of Japan on April 22, 1969, and the US withdrew its naval ships from the Sea of Japan on April 26, 1969. 

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID2949
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19720117 19720122
 HOSTILITYA: 4 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 1 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID2949 occurred in 1972. This was a seizure involving the United States and the Soviet Union. The US Coast Guard seized a Soviet fishing vessel and arrested its captain for fishing illegally and attempting to flee. 

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID2222
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19770409 19770410
 HOSTILITYA: 4 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 1 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID2222 is called the `Seizure of two fishing boats.' It is a seizure involving the Soviet Union, April 9-10 1977. Two Soviet fishing boats were seized off the New England coast for violating the 200-mile territorial waters limit.

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID2224
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19790809 19790810
 HOSTILITYA: 3 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 4 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID2224 is titled a `Capture of U.S. torpedo boat' that occurred on August of 9 and 10 1979. A show of ships involving the Soviet Union, August 9-10. There is no mention of this event in contemporary news sources or in the text sources cited below. 

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID2230
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19840912 19840919
 HOSTILITYA: 1 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 4 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID2230 is a bilateral dispute with the USSR that occurred September 12-19. The Soviets seized a U.S. commercial vessel that accidentally ventured into Soviet waters near Alaska. The ship was released after American protests

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID4174
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19970815 19980215
 HOSTILITYA: 4 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 1 FATALITYB: 0

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID4174
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 19970815 19970831
 HOSTILITYA: 4 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 1 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID4174 On August 15, 1997 the United States Coast Guard seized a Russian fishing boat in the Bering Sea for illegally fishing in American waters. The Russian Duma requested the ship be released in a statement on September 13. There is no indication that the boat was ever released, and some indication that the boat and its gear were confiscated by the United States. 
In 1997 (mid 4174), a Russia fishing boat violated US territorial waters prompting the United States to seize and hold the vessel.

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID4213
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 20000202 20000426
 HOSTILITYA: 4 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 1 FATALITYB: 0

MARITIME-DISPUTE: MID4213
 DYAD: USA RUSSIA/USSR 2365
 DATES: 20000202 20000430
 HOSTILITYA: 4 FATALITYA: 0
 HOSTILITYB: 1 FATALITYB: 0

Discussion:
MID4213 USA patrol boats stopped and detained two Russian tankers suspected of carrying sanctioned Iraq oil from the Persian Gulf. Russian Foreign Minister demanded the immediate release of the tanker.
MID4213 involved the perceived violation of sanctions against Iraq by a Russian oil tanker.
